titleStmt.title: Appendix: Southey and Lloyd MS versions of "This Lime-Tree Bower My Prison" in Parallel Texts

notesStmt.note: Southey Version of This Lime-Tree Bower, from the Griggs edition of Coleridge's letters, sent Monday, 17 July 1797, from Alfoxden, where Coleridge was visiting the Wordsworths, whom he had helped settle in that location three days before, the same day that Charles Lamb left for home. In this version, Sara Fricker is addressed as "Sister." Sara is, however, not included in the walking party in Coleridge's introductory epistolary paragraph.

According to Griggs (I.195, fn 1), the Wordsworths arrived at Nether Stowey from Racedown on 2 July; Sara spilled the hot milk on C's foot on 4 July; and Charles Lamb arrived at Nether Stowey on 7 July, staying until 14 July, the day the Wordsworths moved into Alfoxden.
The paragraph introducing the poem in Coleridge's letter reads as follows:

Charles Lamb has been with me for a week—he left me Friday morning [7/14].—- / The second day after Wordsworth came to me dear Sara accidentally emptied a skillet of boiling milk on my foot, which confined me during the whole time of C. Lamb's stay & still prevents me from all walks longer than a furlong.— While Wordsworth, his Sister, & C. Lamb were out one evening; / sitting in the arbour of T. Poole's garden, which communicates with mine, I wrote these lines, with which I am pleased——

Lloyd Version of This Lime-Tree Bower, sent to Charles Lloyd, ca. July 1797 (?) (evidence for dating not apparent). To judge from regularization of orthography and punctuation ("&" to "and"; dashes to commas, periods, semi-colons; etc.), fewer strikethroughs and revisions, and better conformity to the final published version of 1800, this seems to be a copy of Southey's, or a version following Southey's. In this version, "Sara" is substituted for the word "Sister" in the Southey version.

This transcription comes from the original in the Berg Collection, NYPL. Text missing from torn sections is indicated in brackets and boldface, interpolated from the Southey version or the first published version in The Annual Anthology, 1800, as modified by demands of grammatical consistency (e.g., in fourth to last line).

analytic.title: Southey and Lloyd MS versions of "This Lime-Tree Bower My Prison" in Parallel Texts
analytic.author: Samuel Taylor Coleridge

imprint.publisher: Romantic Circles at the University of Maryland

quotation.p: All quotation marks and apostrophes have been changed: " for “," for ”, ' for ‘, and ' for ’.

hyphenation.p: Any dashes occurring in line breaks have been removed.

normalization.p: Writing in other hands appearing on these manuscripts has been indicated as such, the content recorded in brackets.
& has been used for the ampersand sign.
£ has been used for £, the pound sign
All other characters, those with accents, non-breaking spaces, etc., have been encoded in HTML entity decimals.

app.rdg:
Editor's note: First page, interior of multi-folded letter, which has a long strip partially torn off along most of the space furthest right of the folds, leaving the upper two inches or so intact.
At top of page, one line of the end of what looks like a note about "Ferns," perhaps last line of a note begun at the bottom of the page, a portion now missing, meant as citation for the asterisk before "foliage" in the text. A long solid line underscores this first line at the top, and then the poem begins. the Ferns in high & dry situations are branchy.

lg.l: Well — , they are gone ; ! and here must I remain,

app.rdg: Lam'd by the scathe of fire, lonely and faint,

lg.l: This lime-tree bower my prison. Prison. They, meantime,
My friends, whom I may never meet again,

On springy* Coleridge's note: *elastic I mean springey
heath, Heath, along the hill-top edge Edge

rdg.del: Wand'ring well-pleased, look down on grange or dell
that deep gloomy Rift, where many an Ash

lg.l: Wander delighted, Delighted wander, and look down, perchance,
On that same rifted Dell, where many an the wet Ash
Twists it's wild limbs beside above the ferny rock ,

Whose plumy plumey ferns **Coleridge's note: **the ferns, that grow in moist places, grow five or six together & form a complete 'Prince of Wales's Feather'- i.e. plumey.— [See note to Lloyd letter, top line of page 1, "ferns" and "branchey"— Ed.]
for ever nod and drip
Spray'd by the waterfall. But chiefly thou,
My gentle-hearted Charles! thou, Thou, who hast pin'd
And hunger'd after Nature nature many a year,
In the great City pent, winning thy Thy way,
With sad yet bowed soul, thro' evil and pain
And strange calamity . —- ! Ah slowly sink
Behind the western ridge ; , thou glorious Sun!
Shine in the slant beams of the sinking orb, Orb,
Ye purple Heath-flowers! Heath flowers! Richlier burn, ye Clouds!
Live in the yellow Light, light, ye distant Groves!
And kindle, Thou blue Ocean! So my Friend
Struck with joy's deepest calm, and gazing round deep calm may stand, as I have stood,

app.rdg: Silent, with swimming sense; yea, gazing round

lg.l: On the wide view,+Coleridge's note: +You remember, I am a Berkleian.— may gaze landscape, gaze till all doth seem
Less gross than bodily , — a living Thing
That acts acts upon the mind, and with such hues
As cloathe the Almighty Spirit, when he makes
Spirits perceive His his presence! — A Delight

app.rdg: A Delight

lg.l: Comes sudden on my heart, and I am glad
As I myself were there! Nor in this bower,

app.rdg: Want I sweet sounds or pleasing shapes.
This little lime-tree bower, have I not seen
Much that has sooth'd me. Pale beneath the Light
I watch'd
Hung the transparent foliage; and I watch'd
Many a sunny leaf, and lov'd to see
The sunshine of each broad transparent Leaf
The shadow of the Leaf and lov'd to mark
Broke by the shadows of the Leaf or Stem
The shadow of the Leaf & Stem above

lg.l:
Which hung above it: Dappling it's sunshine!
and And that Wall-nut wall-nut Tree
Was richly-ting'd: and a deep radiance lay
Full on the ancient ivy Ivy, which usurps
Those fronting elms, and now, with blackest mass m[ass]

app.rdg: Makes their dark foliage gleam a lighter hue
Makes their dark *foliage gleam a lighter hue

lg.l:
Thro' the last late
twilight: Twilight: and tho' the rapid bat Bat
Wheels silent by , and not a swallow twitters,
Yet still the solitary humble-bee Humble-bee

Sings in the bean-flower.— Henceforth I shall know k[now]Editor's note: The next line, beginning apparently with the capital letter "T," is cut or torn off from the bottom of the page. Four lines are written as a separate group, lengthwise perpendicular to rest of text, into the right-hand margin, at the top of the page, in a different hand. The beginnings of all four of these lines are missing, from the page margin having been torn vertically up to this point, and then off to the right. Professor Andrew Stauffer suggests that whoever clipped the signature from the bottom of the page overleaf realized s/he was mutilating the poem on this side, and restored the missing lines in the upper margin of the first page.
No scene so narrow, but [No waste so vacant, but] may well employ
Each faculty of sense, and [Each faculty of sense, and] keep the Heart
Awake to Love & Beauty: [Awake to Love and Beauty!] and sometimes Editor's note: Overleaf: At center of page, addressed to "Charles Lloyd Junior/Birmingham" with postmark "Bridgewater."
'Tis well to be bereav'd bereft of promis'd good, Good,
That we may lift the soul, & and contemplate

With lively joy Joy the joys ,
we cannot share.

My Sister, Sara,
& and my Friends! when the last Rook
Beat it's straight path along the dusky Air
Homewards, I bless'd it ; — deeming, it's black wing Wing

rdg.del: orb and blaze of setting day

app.rdg: Had cross'd the mighty Orb's dilated Blaze
Cross'd, like a speck, the blaze of setting day,

lg.l: While ye [While ye] stood gazing; or, when all was still,
Flew creaking [Flew creakin]g o'er your heads, and had a charm
For you, my Sister [For you, my] Sara & my Friends! to whom
No sound is [No sound is] dissonant, which tells of Life ! .

app.rdg: S. T. Coleridge
[ ] observe the 'creek! creek! creek! which the Editor's note: Note at bottom of page—partially torn
[ ] with it's wings, I believe)—when flying high
[R]emember me with the best [illegible] of Editor's note: Farewell at bottom of page—partially torn
[ ] to her, whom you love—& believe

[ ]ver Editor's note: Closing and signature seem to be missing—cut out by a collector?
James Dykes Campbell, in his Poetical Works of Samuel Taylor Coleridge (London: Macmillan, 1893) notes of the poem's series of revisions, on page 592:
"The text of the Annual Anthology [1800, the poem's first appearance in print] differs hardly at all from that of 1829 [a collected edition in three volumes], but at some date unknown to me Coleridge took a pen and, in his own copy [of the 1829 edition], reduced the poem, practically, to its original version as sent to Lloyd [i.e., Version 2 of this parallel edition]."
